00022 #include "Rcpp.h"
00023 
00024 /*
00025  * The following class definitions employ advanced features of the Rcpp
00026  * library and R, permitting the C++ programmer to call user-defined functions
00027  * on the R side. They should be skipped on first reading.
00028  */
00029 
00030 /*
00031  * Define a class that can be used to call an R function that expects a
00032  * real vector argument and returns a scalar. The R function is defined in
00033  * the example section of the documentation page for RcppExample (see
00034  * RcppExample.Rd).
00035  */
00036 class MyRVectorFunc : public RcppFunction {
00037 public:
00038     MyRVectorFunc(SEXP fn) : RcppFunction(fn) {}
00039 
00040     // This trivial function will use an R function to compute the
00041     // sum of the elements of v!
00042     double getSum(std::vector<double>& v) {
00043 
00044         // Turn vector into a SEXP that can be passed to R as an argument.
00045         setRVector(v);
00046 
00047         // Call the R function that was passed in as the paramter fn, with
00048         // the SEXP vector that was just set as its argument.
00049         SEXP result = vectorCall();
00050 
00051         // Assuming that the R function simply returns a real number we
00052         // pass it back to the C++ user as follows. If the R function returns
00053         // something more complicated transform result into a C++ object to
00054         // be returned, and  clear the part of the protection stack due to
00055         // this object before returning (to prevent protection stack overflow).
00056         // Note that it is unsafe to do this if the returned result depends
00057         // on PROTECT-ed SEXP's. For example, result should not be 
00058         // wrapped in a class like RcppParams where objects hold onto the
00059         // the PROTECT-ed SEXP that was used to construct them.
00060 
00061         double value = REAL(result)[0];
00062 
00063         // Safe now to clear the contribution of this function to the
00064         // protection stack.
00065         clearProtectionStack();
00066 
00067         return value;
00068     }
00069 };
00070 
00071 /*
00072  * Define a class that can be used to call an R function that expects a
00073  * heterogeneous list argument, and returns a vector of the same length
00074  * with 1 added to each component (no names). The R function is defined in
00075  * the example section of the documentation page for RcppExample (see
00076  * RcppExample.Rd).
00077  */
00078 class MyRListFunc : public RcppFunction {
00079 public:
00080     MyRListFunc(SEXP fn) : RcppFunction(fn) {}
00081     std::vector<double> addOne(double alpha, double beta, double gamma) {
00082 
00083         // Build argument list.
00084         setRListSize(3);
00085         appendToRList("alpha", alpha);
00086         appendToRList("beta",  beta);
00087         appendToRList("gamma", gamma);
00088 
00089         // Call the R function passed in as fn with the list argument just
00090         // constructed.
00091         SEXP result = listCall();
00092 
00093         // Turn returned R vector into a C++ vector, clear protection stack,
00094         // and return.
00095         std::vector<double> vec(Rf_length(result));
00096         for(int i=0; i < Rf_length(result); i++)
00097             vec[i] = REAL(result)[i];
00098 
00099         // See comments in previous class definition on the purpose of this.
00100         clearProtectionStack();
00101 
00102         return vec;
00103     }
00104 };
00105 
00106 /*
00107  * Sample function illustrates how to use the Rcpp R/C++ interface library.
00108  */
00109 RcppExport SEXP Rcpp_Example(SEXP params, SEXP nlist, 
00110                              SEXP numvec, SEXP nummat,
00111                              SEXP df, SEXP datevec, SEXP stringvec,
00112                              SEXP fnvec, SEXP fnlist) {
00113 
00114     SEXP rl=R_NilValue; // Use this when there is nothing to be returned.
00115     char *exceptionMesg=NULL;
00116 
00117     try {
00118 
00119         int i=0, j=0;
00120 
00121         // Get parameters in params.
00122         RcppParams rparam(params);
00123         std::string method = rparam.getStringValue("method");
00124         double tolerance = rparam.getDoubleValue("tolerance");
00125         int    maxIter = rparam.getIntValue("maxIter");
00126         RcppDate startDate = rparam.getDateValue("startDate");
00127 
00128         // The output of commands like this may not appear under Windows.
00129         Rprintf("Parsing start date argument: %d/%d/%d\n", 
00130                 startDate.getMonth(),
00131                 startDate.getDay(),
00132                 startDate.getYear());
00133 
00134         // QuantLib note: an RcppDate is automatically converted to QuantLib
00135         // Date when the context calls for this, provided 
00136         // USING_QUANTLIB is set.
00137 
00138         RcppDateVector dateVec(datevec);
00139         //dateVec(0) = RcppDate(12, 15, 1989); // update one element.
00140 
00141         RcppStringVector stringVec(stringvec);
00142         //stringVec(1) = string("New York"); // update one element.
00143 
00144         // and nl.getValue(i) to fetch data.
00145         RcppNumList nl(nlist);
00146 
00147         // numvec parameter viewed as vector of ints (with truncation).
00148         //RcppVector<int> vecI(numvec);
00149 
00150         // mat parameter viewed as matrix of ints (with truncation).
00151         //RcppMatrix<int> matI(nummat);
00152 
00153         // vec parameter viewed as vector of doubles.
00154         RcppVector<double> vecD(numvec);
00155 
00156         // mat parameter viewed as matrix of doubles.
00157         RcppMatrix<double> matD(nummat);
00158 
00159         // Do some computations with the matrices.
00160         int nrows = matD.getDim1();
00161         int ncols = matD.getDim2();
00162         for(i = 0; i < nrows; i++)
00163             for(j = 0; j < ncols; j++)
00164                 matD(i,j) = 2 * matD(i,j);
00165 
00166         int len = vecD.size();
00167         for(i = 0; i < len; i++)
00168             vecD(i) = 3 * vecD(i);
00169 
00170         // Get copy of matrix/vector in standard (unchecked) C/C++ format.
00171         // May be useful when these vectors need to be passed to
00172         // C/C++ code that does not know about Rcpp classes...
00173         double **a = matD.cMatrix();
00174         double  *v = vecD.cVector();
00175 
00176         // ...or we might want to use an STL container...
00177         std::vector<double> stlvec(vecD.stlVector());
00178         nrows = (int)stlvec.size();
00179         for(i = 0; i < nrows; i++)
00180             stlvec[i] += 1;
00181 
00182         // ...or perhaps a container of containers.
00183         std::vector<std::vector<double> > stlmat(matD.stlMatrix());
00184         nrows = (int)stlmat.size();
00185         ncols = (int)stlmat[0].size();
00186         for(i = 0; i < nrows; i++)
00187             for(j = 0; j < ncols; j++)
00188                 stlmat[i][j] += 2;
00189 
00190         // Get a zero matrix the same size as matD.
00191         //RcppMatrix<double> matZ(nrows, ncols);
00192 
00193         // Make a vector of strings
00194         std::vector<std::string> svec(2);
00195         svec[0] = "hello";
00196         svec[1] = "world";
00197 
00198         // Process the input data frame and show factors and dates.
00199         RcppFrame inframe(df);
00200 
00201         /*
00202         Rprintf("\nFactors and Dates in frame...");
00203         vector<vector<ColDatum> > table = inframe.getTableData();
00204         int nrow = table.size();
00205         int ncol = table[0].size();
00206         for(int row=0; row < nrow; row++) {
00207             for(int col=0; col < ncol; col++) {
00208                 RcppDate d;
00209                 string name;
00210                 int level;
00211                 switch(table[row][col].getType()) {
00212                 case COLTYPE_FACTOR:
00213                     level = table[row][col].getFactorLevel();
00214                     name  = table[row][col].getFactorLevelName();
00215                     Rprintf("Level, name: %d, %s\n",
00216                             level, name.c_str());
00217                     break;
00218                 case COLTYPE_DATE:
00219                     d = table[row][col].getDateValue();
00220                     Rprintf("Start Date: %d/%d/%d\n", 
00221                             d.getMonth(),
00222                             d.getDay(),
00223                             d.getYear());
00224                     break;
00225                 default:
00226                     ; // Ignore other types.
00227                 }
00228             }
00229         }
00230         */
00231 
00232         // Make a pre-data frame, that is, a list object that when passed
00233         // the the R function data.frame() will return a data frame with
00234         // the specified column names and data types. The first row added
00235         // determines the types for all columns.
00236         int numCol=4;
00237         std::vector<std::string> colNames(numCol);
00238         colNames[0] = "alpha"; // column of strings
00239         colNames[1] = "beta";  // column of reals
00240         colNames[2] = "gamma"; // factor column
00241         colNames[3] = "delta"; // column of Dates
00242         RcppFrame frame(colNames);
00243 
00244         // Third column will be a factor. In the current implementation the
00245         // level names are copied to every factor value (and factors
00246         // in the same column must have the same level names). The level names
00247         // for a particular column will be factored out (pardon the pun) in
00248         // a future release.
00249         int numLevels = 2;
00250         std::string *levelNames = new std::string[2];
00251         levelNames[0] = std::string("pass"); // level 1
00252         levelNames[1] = std::string("fail"); // level 2
00253 
00254         // First row (this one determines column types).
00255         std::vector<ColDatum> row1(numCol);
00256         row1[0].setStringValue("a");
00257         row1[1].setDoubleValue(3.14);
00258         row1[2].setFactorValue(levelNames, numLevels, 1);
00259         row1[3].setDateValue(RcppDate(7,4,2006));
00260         frame.addRow(row1);
00261 
00262         // Second row.
00263         std::vector<ColDatum> row2(numCol);
00264         row2[0].setStringValue("b");
00265         row2[1].setDoubleValue(6.28);
00266         row2[2].setFactorValue(levelNames, numLevels, 1);
00267         row2[3].setDateValue(RcppDate(12,25,2006));
00268         frame.addRow(row2);
00269 
00270         // Done with levelNames.
00271         delete [] levelNames;
00272 
00273         // Test MyRVectorFunction defined above...
00274         MyRVectorFunc vfunc(fnvec);
00275         int n = 10;
00276         std::vector<double> vecInput(n);
00277         for(int i=0; i < n; i++)
00278             vecInput[i] = i;
00279         double vecSum = vfunc.getSum(vecInput);
00280         Rprintf("Testing vector function argument: vecSum = %lf\n", vecSum);
00281         
00282         // Test MyRListFunction defined above...
00283         MyRListFunc lfunc(fnlist);
00284         double alpha=1, beta=2, gamma=3;
00285         std::vector<double> vecOut = lfunc.addOne(alpha, beta, gamma);
00286         Rprintf("Testing list function argument: %lf, %lf, %lf\n", vecOut[0], vecOut[1], vecOut[2]);
00287 
00288         RcppDate aDate(12, 25, 1999);
00289 
00290         // Build result set to be returned as a list to R.
00291         RcppResultSet rs;
00292 
00293         rs.add("date", aDate);
00294         rs.add("dateVec", dateVec);
00295         rs.add("method", method);
00296         rs.add("tolerance", tolerance);
00297         rs.add("maxIter", maxIter);
00298         rs.add("nlFirstName", nl.getName(0));
00299         rs.add("nlFirstValue", nl.getValue(0));
00300         rs.add("matD", matD);
00301         rs.add("stlvec", stlvec);
00302         rs.add("stlmat", stlmat);
00303         rs.add("a", a, nrows, ncols);
00304         rs.add("v", v, len);
00305         rs.add("stringVec", stringVec);
00306         rs.add("strings", svec);
00307         rs.add("InputDF", inframe);
00308         rs.add("PreDF", frame);
00309 
00310 
00311         // Instead of returning selected input parameters as we did in
00312         // the last three statements, the entire input parameter list
00313         // can be returned like this:
00314         rs.add("params", params, false);
00315 
00316 
00317         // Get the list to be returned to R.
00318         rl = rs.getReturnList();
00319         
00320     } catch(std::exception& ex) {
00321         exceptionMesg = copyMessageToR(ex.what());
00322     } catch(...) {
00323         exceptionMesg = copyMessageToR("unknown reason");
00324     }
00325     
00326     if(exceptionMesg != NULL)
00327         Rf_error(exceptionMesg);
00328 
00329     return rl;
00330 }
00331 
00332 
00333 RcppExport SEXP RcppParamsExample(SEXP params) {
00334 
00335     SEXP rl=R_NilValue; // Use this when there is nothing to be returned.
00336     char *exceptionMesg=NULL;
00337 
00338     try {
00339 
00340         // Get parameters in params.
00341         RcppParams rparam(params);
00342         std::string method      = rparam.getStringValue("method");
00343         double tolerance   = rparam.getDoubleValue("tolerance");
00344         int    maxIter     = rparam.getIntValue("maxIter");
00345         RcppDate startDate = rparam.getDateValue("startDate");
00346         
00347         Rprintf("\nIn C++, seeing the following value\n");
00348         Rprintf("Method argument    : %s\n", method.c_str());
00349         Rprintf("Tolerance argument : %f\n", tolerance);
00350         Rprintf("MaxIter argument   : %d\n", maxIter);
00351         Rprintf("Start date argument: %04d-%02d-%02d\n", 
00352                 startDate.getYear(), startDate.getMonth(), startDate.getDay());
00353 
00354         // Build result set to be returned as a list to R.
00355         RcppResultSet rs;
00356 
00357         rs.add("method",    method);
00358         rs.add("tolerance", tolerance);
00359         rs.add("maxIter",   maxIter);
00360         rs.add("startDate", startDate);
00361 
00362         // Instead of returning selected input parameters as we did in
00363         // the last statements, the entire input parameter list can be
00364         // returned like this:
00365         rs.add("params", params, false);  // 'false' to not PROTECT params
00366 
00367         // Get the list to be returned to R.
00368         rl = rs.getReturnList();
00369         
00370     } catch(std::exception& ex) {
00371         exceptionMesg = copyMessageToR(ex.what());
00372     } catch(...) {
00373         exceptionMesg = copyMessageToR("unknown reason");
00374     }
00375     
00376     if(exceptionMesg != NULL)
00377         Rf_error(exceptionMesg);
00378 
00379     return rl;
00380 }
00381 
00382 RcppExport SEXP RcppDateExample(SEXP dvsexp, SEXP dtvsexp) {
00383 
00384     SEXP rl=R_NilValue; // Use this when there is nothing to be returned.
00385     char *exceptionMesg=NULL;
00386 
00387     try {
00388 
00389         RcppDateVector dv(dvsexp);
00390         RcppDatetimeVector dtv(dtvsexp);
00391         
00392         Rprintf("\nIn C++, seeing the following date value\n");
00393         for (int i=0; i<dv.size(); i++) {
00394             std::cout << dv(i) << std::endl;
00395             dv(i) = dv(i) + 7;          // shift a week
00396         }
00397         Rprintf("\nIn C++, seeing the following datetime value\n");
00398         for (int i=0; i<dtv.size(); i++) {
00399             std::cout << dtv(i) << std::endl;
00400             dtv(i) = dtv(i) + 0.250;    // shift 250 millisec
00401         }
00402 
00403         // Build result set to be returned as a list to R.
00404         RcppResultSet rs;
00405         rs.add("date",   dv);
00406         rs.add("datetime", dtv);
00407 
00408         // Get the list to be returned to R.
00409         rl = rs.getReturnList();
00410         
00411     } catch(std::exception& ex) {
00412         exceptionMesg = copyMessageToR(ex.what());
00413     } catch(...) {
00414         exceptionMesg = copyMessageToR("unknown reason");
00415     }
00416     
00417     if(exceptionMesg != NULL)
00418         Rf_error(exceptionMesg);
00419 
00420     return rl;
00421 }
00422 
00423 RcppExport SEXP RcppVectorExample(SEXP vector) {
00424 
00425     SEXP rl=R_NilValue; // Use this when there is nothing to be returned.
00426     char *exceptionMesg=NULL;
00427 
00428     try {
00429 
00430         // Get parameters in params.
00431         RcppVector<int> vec(vector);
00432         int n = vec.size();
00433 
00434         Rprintf("\nIn C++, seeing a vector of length %d\n", n);
00435 
00436         // create a C++ STL vector, and reserve appropriate size
00437         std::vector<double> res(n);
00438         
00439         for (int i=0; i<n; i++) {
00440             res[i] = sqrt(static_cast<double>(vec(i)));
00441         }
00442 
00443         // Build result set to be returned as a list to R.
00444         RcppResultSet rs;
00445 
00446         rs.add("result",  res);
00447         rs.add("original", vec);
00448 
00449         // Get the list to be returned to R.
00450         rl = rs.getReturnList();
00451         
00452     } catch(std::exception& ex) {
00453         exceptionMesg = copyMessageToR(ex.what());
00454     } catch(...) {
00455         exceptionMesg = copyMessageToR("unknown reason");
00456     }
00457     
00458     if(exceptionMesg != NULL)
00459         Rf_error(exceptionMesg);
00460 
00461     return rl;
00462 }
